title: 111_s3888
content:
The "End Debt Collector Abuse Act of 2010" may be cited as the short title. Enhanced validation notices are included in the act. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include new requirements for debt collectors, such as providing the date of the last payment, the amount of debt at default, the name and address of the last creditor, an itemization of the debt, and the consumer's rights to request communication cessation. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include new requirements for debt collectors, such as providing consumer communication options, stopping collection efforts upon request, and disclosing a contact person for complaints. This section and its amendments will take effect one year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 3. DISPUTE INVESTIGATIONS AND VERIFICATION.

Amends the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act to require debt collectors to conduct a thorough investigation and provide specific information and verification when a debt is disputed by the consumer.

SEC. 4. AWARD OF DAMAGES. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include an adjustment for inflation in damages awarded to consumers. The Consumer Price Index will be used to determine the percentage increase in amounts set forth in the section. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include an adjustment for inflation in damages awarded to consumers. The Consumer Price Index will determine the percentage increase in amounts set forth in the section, with annual adjustments made accordingly. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to include inflation adjustments in damages awarded to consumers for violations. Increases in amounts set forth in the Act will apply to failures to comply occurring after the enactment date. Additionally, injunctive relief may be awarded in civil actions for violations of the Act. The Fair Debt Collection Practices Act is amended to prohibit debt collectors from seeking a warrant for the arrest of a debtor as an unfair debt collection practice. This amendment does not limit a court's ability to hold a debtor in civil contempt or a debt collector's ability to seek other remedies to satisfy a debt judgment.
